pr_title: [RW-4884] Expose the GCS bucket name to the workspace admin page and fetch-workspace-details tool

timeline.bodyText: It's almost  worth making an AbstractApplicationRunListener with empty overrides for everything and extending that so you only have methods that actually do things in this class.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Not worth creating two class files for one line of code, IMO
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: It would be great to have a comment specific to this implementation of the method giving the why/how, etc. Could this break any existing code (ours or anyone else's) that depends on this scope, or is the idea that it will be clobbered later on in the application startup and be associated with the usual scope and properties, etc.

replies.bodyText: Could be nice, but sounds pretty hypothetical. I'd rather not end up with more files floating around here.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: nit/tangent: I didn't know about this class (haven't worked with the tools much), but a couple of our other configs are named with a SpringConfiguration suffix (to distinguish from other config classes). I navigate randomly so much that I forget to look at package names, though I'm getting better.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText:
Was this meant to be attached to the CommandLineToolConfig file?
I also got annoyed at that naming degeneracy at some point. We have many, many more Spring configs than other configs, so I'd probably bend towards adding a suffix to non-Spring config files if we did need to add clarity. (Something like "AppConfig" or "ConfigModel" might be clear.)
But I've mostly just accepted that there's probably no great solution here.
replies.author: gjuggler

replies.bodyText: I was confused mainly on why FileWorkspaceDetails seems to have @Configuration in it. But maybe all the tools work that way.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Ah – yes, all the tools work this way. Technically, it's just a configuration that provides a @CommandLineRunner bean. Spring docs for that annotation: Interface used to indicate that a bean should run when it is contained within a {@link SpringApplication}. It's a bit roundabout, but it's definitely the most reliable setup we've had for CLI tools yet.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: Is it possible to pull in the WorkspaceAdminService (or other high-level service) instead? Some of this information is already being compiled for the admin page. There are a ton of transient dependencies though, so I can understand why you wouldn't.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Maybe it's possible, but I don't think it would be preferable. I'm pulling in the smallest service that has the methods needed for this PR, which I think is the right thing to do, dependency-wise.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: nit: maybe name this ToolApplicationRunListener so it's more obvious when it gets pulled in.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: Good idea – I renamed to CommandLineToolApplicationRunListener for (1) consistency with CommandLineToolConfig and (2) ApproachingPeakJavaCamelCase
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.message: Add GCS bucket path to the workpace admin UI and CLI.
Add some comments and use a typed reference to the Request scope magic string.
